title: Why does group 1 and 2 element react with group 6 and 7 elements to form an electrovalent compound? - Quora

response.answer_text: Group 1 and 2 elements have 1 and 2 electron respectively extra. Hence they can donate these extra electrons to becomes electrically stable/ neutral. Whereas Group 6 and 7 elements have 2 and 1 electrons short to becomes neutral. Since there are donors and acceptors and whenever they come close to each other the electrons get shared and they form some compound by exchange of electrons. For eg Na +1 with Cl -1 forms NaClMg 2ith +2 joins S -2 to form MgS

The first group gives up electrons (1,2) and become positively charged ions and the second group accepts electrons (1,2) and become negatively charged ions. The process stabilises the last orbits of the atoms like adjoining Inert gases.
